BALTIMORE, MD., OCTOBER 15, 1917.

PRICE, FIVE CENTS

GETTYSBURG GAME ENDS IN TIE

TRACK ORGANIZATION THURSDAY

CORPS WILL HAVE RIFLE RANGE

ENGINEERING SCHOOL DEPLETED

Hopkins Team Puts Up Game Fight
Against Heavier Eleven—Wolfe and
Purcell Stars-100 Rooters
Accompany Team.

Coach England and Captain Firor to
Give Plans—Large Squad Desired.
Candidates Excused From
Thursday Drill.

High Calibre Range Being Planned for.
Officers to Carry Swagger Sticks—Recruit Company Learning Quickly.
Heavy Penalty for Absence.

One Fourth of Civil Engineering Faculty
Enlisted—Many Students Receive
Commissions—Night Course
Being Conducted.

The Johns Hopkins football
team last Saturday fought the
heavy Gettysburg team to a standstill, the game ending in a tie, 6
to 6. It was a thrilling game; full
of good tackling, long end runs,
dashing line plunges and sensaAlthough out.tional passes.
weighed at least ten pounds to the
man, the Hopkins crew was more
than a match for their big opponents and even outplayed them in
the latter stages of the game.
For the first time in many a day,
a Hopkins team went to fight in
foreign territory accompanied by
a real, live crowd of rooters. The
band of 100 Hopkins men who
yelled their encouragement and approval to their fellows on the gridiron Saturday were fully rewarded for their spirit. Captain Guild,
of the faculty, and Captain Elliott,
his predecessor as professor of
military science and tactics, rooted their hardest for the Black and
Blue, as did many more of the officers and soldiers from the Regular Army regiments stationed at
Gettysburg. The team appreci.ated their whole-hearted support
and responded by fighting every
minute of the four periods by holding the Gettysburgers well in
check.
Alec Wolfe became the hero of
the game when he caught a 25yard forward pass from Carey off
a Gettysburg man's chest and
planted the ball under the goal
posts for Hopkins' only score.
But he was not the only star.
Purcell ran back Rote's punts in
magnificent style and played for
three periods with a bad leg;
Jones plowed through the strong
Gettysburg line time and again
for substantial gains; Cashell
played a great defensive game;
Carey threw the pass that tied the
score; and the line was both a
stone wall on the defense and a
steel wedge on the offense. Winslow outpunted Rote and killed
many and embryo end run. Capt.
Dick Woodward was in the game
With all the old fight and pep.
Gettysburg started off with a
rush, but Hopkins soon found itself and settled down. Rote, soon
after the kick-off, broke loose for
a 65-yard run to the Hopkins 15yard line, where Winslow managed to spill him through a pretty
Piece of headwork. Winslow
Slowed him up by balking him, and
then made a sure, hard tackle. The
Hopkins line stiffened, threw the
Gettysburgers back for losses, in-

Because of the arising of unforeseen difficulties, the organization meeting of the track team of
1917-18 was not held last Wednesday as was planned, but was
postponed until this Thursday at
12.30 o'clock. All the old men
and all candidates are to meet at
that hour in the lecture hall of the
Civil Engineering Building, where
Coach Joseph T. England, Capt.
Monroe Firor and Manager Carroll will outline the program of
the year and tell the men of the
traditions to be upheld.
Since Captain Firor is attending the Medical School and cannot
be on hand about Homewood, except at practices, Beverly Smith,
captain of last year's freshman
team and a member of the 'Varsity relay, will assist him in taking charge of the undergraduate
candidates. Guy Leadbetter, a
second-year medical student and
graduate of Bowdoin, will help
the coach again this year by instructing candidates in field work
and will add materially to the
success of the squad by his ability
in the weight events.
A number of former stars of
other universities, who are now in
the Medical School, have been discovered by Firor, and have signified their intention of becoming
members of the squad. Also a
number of sprinters graduated
from Baltimore"prep"schoolsore
working_ out on the cross-country
course with last year's men.
The course is in better shape
than it has been for years, and is
marked all the way by posts painted white. It is approximately two
miles in length. The management
of the team, however, in order to
make sure of the distance covered,
is arranging to have it surveyed,
and this job may be taken over by
some of the engineering students.
If the plans now under consideration are adopted a number of large
cross country meets will be held
on it.
Coach England is desirous of
a large attendance at the organization meeting, as the schedule
now being arranged will require
a big squad to carry it through.
Since this year offers exceptional
opportunities for freshmen, it is
hoped that they will turn out in
large numbers.
All candidates for the track team
have been excused from drill on
Thursdays by Captain Guild.
They must attend the other drills
and lectures, however.

The Johns Hopkins Reserve Officers' Training Corps is to have a
full calibre rifle range or its equivalent by the spring of 1918. According to Captain Guild, plans
the present time are necessarily uncertain, but unless something unforeseen happens Hopkins
is sure to have at least a low calibre range in which the work of a
full calibre range will be closely
simulated, and which will be of
almost equal value to the student
officers.
It is now ungrtain whether the
Johns HopkinW corps will be, allowed to retain the Krag rifles obtained last year from the War Department. It is the' opinion of
Captain Guild that such an event
4 not unlikely in view of the great
need for rifles at the present time.
Should the rifles have to be turned
in, the use of a full range would
of course be out of the question,
and the lower calibre range would
have to be substituted.
A suitable distinguishing device
for the Johns Hopkins Corps,
probably an adaptation of the
Johns Hopkins seal, is to be worn
on the campaign hats and swagger
sticks are to be carried by the officers as an insignia of rank.
The officers of the corps express
praticular satisfaction with regard to the work of the• recruit
company. The progress has been
such as to warrant the prediction
that the recruit company as a distinct unit will soon be a thing of
the past.
General orders issued last Friday set the program for drills and
outline the conduct of both individuals and battalion for the coming year. On drill days the first
call is to be at 4.05 P. M., the assembly at 4.10 and the recall at 6.
Monday and Thursday are set as
drill days for the entire battalion,
and Tuesday for optional drills
for the companies in rotation.
During inclement weather assembly will take place in the driveway
tunnel of Gilman Hall.
Particular stress 'is laid upon
the necessity of the elimination
of lateness and tardiness in the
companies. Opportunities to make
up drills will be given but the
'be espepenalties this year will
cially heavy, ana every effort will
be made to stamp out the evil.
Captain Guild strongly recommends the wearing of the uniform
at all times by the men.

The membership of the faculty
and students of the engineering
department has been greatly reduced by enlistments in war service.
One fourth of last year's faculty
of the department of civil engineering is now engaged in war
work. Professor Frank L. Weaver, instructor in civil engineering,
is a first lieutenant in the 305th
Engineers, U. S. A., stationed at
Fort Lee, Va.
Of a class of twelve juniors in
civil engineering last year, five
have returned as seniors; the remaining seven are in the army.
An addition of about three hundred volumes has been made during the summer to the library of
the civil engineering department.
In the department of electrical
engineering, Dr. J. B. Whitehead
and Dr. William B. Kouwenhoven
have been engaged in Government
service during the summer. Dr.
Whitehead is now devoting all and
Dr. Kouwenhoven part of his time
to scientific research work for the
Government. Dr. Kouwenhoven
and Mr. M. W. Pullen, instructor
in eletcrical engineering, have
charge of Dr. Whitehead's day
classes.
The night courses in electrical
engineering are in charge of Mr.
F. W. Lieberknecht and J. B. Arthur, instructor in electrical engineering in the U. S. Naval
Academy.
Henry S. Baker, Elbridge G.
Hall and Louis McComas Young,
former students, have commissions
in the army.
There are seven in the senior
class in electrical engineering
this year, as compared with nine
last year. Twenty-five juniors
have returned in this course.
In the department of mechanical
engineering, Mr. Julian C. Smallwood, instructor in mechanical
engineering, has charge of the day
and night classes in machine design this year.
Prof. Carl C. Thomas, professor
of mechanical engineering,who has
been appointed head of the Maritime Navigation Schools of the
U. S. Shipping Board, has charge
of the day and night courses in
navigation and maritime,engineering. He will be assisted by Instructor William J. Dand in the
day courses and by Prof. J. G.
Russell and Howard Lyons, both
of the faculty of the U. S. Naval
Academy, in the night courses in
marine engineering. Mr. W. M.

The first organization meeting
of the Johns Hopkins Musical
Clubs, held on Tuesday, October
9, was well attended. Manager
Kellum gave a brief outline of the
work to be done during the coming year.
It was announced that the work
of the clubs during the past has
gained them a number of excellent
bookings for this season, and that
the financial outlook is good. Assurances were given of the return
of Mr. Spieker as director.
Glee and Musical Club practice
will be held on Wednesday and
Monday nights, respectively.

$250 IS UNDERGRADUATE GOAL
Dr. Raney, Hopkins Librarian, Calls on
Students to Contribute at Once
and Show Reasons for
Appeal.

At a mass-meeting a week ago
Wednesday, Dr. M. Llewellyn Raney, librarian of the Johns Hopkins University, made an appeal
for student contribution to the
Library Fund for Soldiers and
Sailors, and a clock was set up
over the postoffice window to show
the amounts subscribed. The hand
has stuck at $73.50. The following is a further appeal from Dr.
Raney, who is in charge of the
raising of the fund at Hopkins:
The optimist may often find it
difficult to get a toe-hold in present day events, but it is well worth
a tenacious remembrance that
books for soldiers and sailors have
place in the measures adopted by
the War and Navy Departments
in this conflict. A military measure, not one philanthropic. Germany saw this first, and when her
troops took the field a traveling
library accompanied each army
corps. In her endless rehearsals
for"Der Tag"she had discovered in
books .a piece of stage business
necessary for getting the play over
the footlights. England awoke to
it, as to much else, when the call
for books came from the men themselves in training, on the firing
line, in the hospital—a call overwhelming all existing agencies for
supply. Four organizations born
in succession have failed to meet
the demand, though one of them
has sent 9,000,000 books and periodicals, and the four of them today
despatch 100,000 a week.
•
Our Secretary of War, a Hopkins man, is a political idealist,
but when, under his auspices, a
call for $1,000,000 for books goes
to America, it is the call of a practical militarist. In books soldiers,
no matter what their previous habits as to reading have been, have
found the anodyne necessary for
forgetting the unnatural present,
preserving the balance necessary
to effective military service, and
the means of keeping somewhat
in contact with the life civilian
that is to follow.
This is the first, the last and the
only call that the Government has
issued to educational institutions
as such. The response in Baltimore of such institutions has been
splenaid. The public school children have massed up their pennies
to a height of over $1,670. From
Goucher will come $750 from
Johns Hopkins to date over $1,650 has come, but the readers of
THE NEWS-LETTER have not yet
given their amount. The undergraduate body has to date contributed $73.50. It should not be
satisfied with a red cent less than
$250. Wake up boys! Come
across!

Corn stalks standing in the
shock and dried-up plants are the
remaining evidence of the success
of what was dubbed last spring
"The Faculty Farm:" It is said
that the gardens planted last
May north of the Johns Hopkins
Club grew green and promising
and parts even bore fruit. Much
of the produce, however, suffered
because of the ravages of ravenous
grasshoppers and the unexpected
sprouting of weeds. Many of
those, however, who industriously
cared for their gardens enjoyed
the produce of their labors at the
dinner table.
All those students who last year
harbored doubts that such an enterprise could attain the point of
fruition would have received a severe shock if they visited the vegetable gardens early this summer.
They will find out that a Greek
professor knows just as much
about beans as about the Iliad,
and that the chemistry man has
achieved a distinct success with
beets and onions.
One of the largest harvests was
the corn crop. A gentleman farmer of the faculty, when interviewed, claimed that his particular garden had on it more ears of
corn per square foot than any
other farm in the State. As he is
a professor of mathematics he is
willing to furnish statistics to
prove his contentions.
Many of the other gardens had
remarkable rows of corn, but their
beans ran a close second. The lima
bean crop was unusually large;
and this delicacy must have been
very popular, for on close observation of the plants it is seen that
hardly a bean has been overlooked
and allowed to remain unplucked.
Many headless stalks of cabbage
may be observed. However, the
disappearance of the heads remain
a mystery, since, as one would-be
farmer remarked,"sauerkraut was
'verboten' by the declaration of
war."
Now the gardens, once such a
scene of industrious hoeing and
planting, stand neglected, awaiting recultivation next spring;
but it has been reported by a
visionary student that the ghost
of the scarecrow is still keeping
watch over his domain.

"Join the Battalion."
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

Sir—Even in this time of national stress some of us seem to be
unmindful of the tremendous responsibilities which rest upon us.
Our sense of duty should become
the greater when considered that
we are members of an institution
which is foremost in the ranks to
offer all that it has to its country.
The professors of our faculty have
proven themselves invaluable to
the Government. What have we,
as undergraduates of Hopkins, to
offer our country when it calls us?
Above all other things we want to
be able to give an acute mind and
a sound body.
Probably there has been no better opportunity in the history of
the University to show at once
loyalty to our Alma Mater and patriotism to our country than that
afforded by the Reserve Officers'
Training Corps. I appeal especially to the upper classmen who
are looking lightly upon military
training. The degree of seriousnegs with which the question
Should be considered cannot be
over-estimated. That you are
benefiting yourself by joining the
corps is trivial; that you are aiding your country in earnestness
of spirit is the all-important feature. Join the battalion—it is a
Government institution. Where
are the "loyal sons of Hopkins?"
Let's have some real, old-time Hopkins spirit! A little pep!

freshmen—look on the regulations
as no more than a mild form of
hazing to make new students uncomfortable. This childish idea,
of course, has no place in the real
purpose of putting these restrictions upon the behavior of freshmen. The actual motive behind it
all, as I see it, is making the
new men loyal, • working, living
parts of the one great organism—
the Johns Hopkins University.
First of all, the first-year student
must be made to realize that when
he.enters the University he is being made heir to all that has been
left by those who have gone before—to its splendid enducational
advantages, to its glorious traditions, to its opportunities for selfbetterment. He must be impressed
by the earnestness, the dignity of
the institution; he must feel the
significance of linking his name
with that of a university whose
reputation for the zealous pursuit
of learning is little less than
world-wide. He should thrill with
the sense of loyalty to that institution; with a feeling of deep obligation that cannot be repaid; with
a consciousness of the duty to uphold its good name at any cost.
And at the same time, he sould be
aware of his individual littleness
in the great complexity of the University; he should realize his extreme relative unimportance. After all, the secret of it all is in humility—not in humiliation. And if
the first-year men will regard them
in this light, the freshman regulations will go far in accomplishing
their aim.

October 13, 1917.

CONSTITUTION BEING DRAWN UP
Hopkins Advisory Council for Interscholastic Athletic League Making
Fall Plans—Opinions of School
Athletic Associations Solicited.

The Hopkins Advisory Council
for the Interscholastic Athletic
League of the Preparatory Schools
of Baltimore, which was founded
last spring by Mr. Theodore Kistler, instructor of gymnastics at
the University, will hold its first
meeting of the year at an early
date. Plans for the coming year
are being formulated by Monroe
Firor, secretary of the Council,
and it is probable that the immediate work of the Hopkins men will
be to supervise interscholastic
basket-ball.
A committee, on which Firor
and President Wolfe, of the Athletic Association are serving, is
now engaged in drawing up a constitution. The athletic associations of the city "prep" schools
have been asked to send in their
opinion as to what the character
and limitations of the league
should be and express the immediate desires of their schools in regard to interscholastic athletics.
These statements are to be influential in determining the scope of
the constitution.
The Council, which is composed
of former members of Baltimore
preparatory schools, has as its
purpose the stimulation and supervision of sports among "prep"
schools. Last spring it offered a
trophy to the champion baseball
team of the city, but made no
award because of a dispute which
arose as to which institution was
the rightful winner. During this
year, however if its plans become
effective, the'
Council will play a
large part in furthering friendly
athletic relations among the city
schools.

The first official figures for student enrollment at the University
this year have been given out by
the registrar's office. In view of
the numerous enlistments during
last spring and summer, these figures will be of special interest to
the members of the upper classes
who are anxious to know just
where they stand.
There are 47 men enrolled in
the Senior Class; this number inincludes the engineering men who
entered with the present Junior
Class and who are completing the
course in three years. The Senior
Class has also been augmented by
a number of men who entered
college this year or last year
with credit from outside colleges.
The Senior Class, therefore,'will
be much larger than was generally
expected. On the other hand, the
Junior Class numbers only 60,
which is much below the general
estimate of its class officers. One
hundred and thirty men, out of
the 157 who finished their first
year, returned as members of the
Sophomore Class. The Freshman
Class has 161 members enrolled—
approximately the same number
of men who entered the University
last year. There are four students
following special courses at the
University. This makes a total of
404 undergraduates for the new
academic year.

TRACK ORGANIZATION THURSDAY

CORPS WILL HAVE RIFLE RANGE

ENGINEERING SCHOOL DEPLETED

Hopkins Team Puts Up Game Fight
Against Heavier Eleven—Wolfe and
Purcell Stars-100 Rooters
Accompany Team.

Coach England and Captain Firor to
Give Plans—Large Squad Desired.
Candidates Excused From
Thursday Drill.

High Calibre Range Being Planned for.
Officers to Carry Swagger Sticks—Recruit Company Learning Quickly.
Heavy Penalty for Absence.

One Fourth of Civil Engineering Faculty
Enlisted—Many Students Receive
Commissions—Night Course
Being Conducted.

The Johns Hopkins football
team last Saturday fought the
heavy Gettysburg team to a standstill, the game ending in a tie, 6
to 6. It was a thrilling game; full
of good tackling, long end runs,
dashing line plunges and sensaAlthough out.tional passes.
weighed at least ten pounds to the
man, the Hopkins crew was more
than a match for their big opponents and even outplayed them in
the latter stages of the game.
For the first time in many a day,
a Hopkins team went to fight in
foreign territory accompanied by
a real, live crowd of rooters. The
band of 100 Hopkins men who
yelled their encouragement and approval to their fellows on the gridiron Saturday were fully rewarded for their spirit. Captain Guild,
of the faculty, and Captain Elliott,
his predecessor as professor of
military science and tactics, rooted their hardest for the Black and
Blue, as did many more of the officers and soldiers from the Regular Army regiments stationed at
Gettysburg. The team appreci.ated their whole-hearted support
and responded by fighting every
minute of the four periods by holding the Gettysburgers well in
check.
Alec Wolfe became the hero of
the game when he caught a 25yard forward pass from Carey off
a Gettysburg man's chest and
planted the ball under the goal
posts for Hopkins' only score.
But he was not the only star.
Purcell ran back Rote's punts in
magnificent style and played for
three periods with a bad leg;
Jones plowed through the strong
Gettysburg line time and again
for substantial gains; Cashell
played a great defensive game;
Carey threw the pass that tied the
score; and the line was both a
stone wall on the defense and a
steel wedge on the offense. Winslow outpunted Rote and killed
many and embryo end run. Capt.
Dick Woodward was in the game
With all the old fight and pep.
Gettysburg started off with a
rush, but Hopkins soon found itself and settled down. Rote, soon
after the kick-off, broke loose for
a 65-yard run to the Hopkins 15yard line, where Winslow managed to spill him through a pretty
Piece of headwork. Winslow
Slowed him up by balking him, and
then made a sure, hard tackle. The
Hopkins line stiffened, threw the
Gettysburgers back for losses, in-

Because of the arising of unforeseen difficulties, the organization meeting of the track team of
1917-18 was not held last Wednesday as was planned, but was
postponed until this Thursday at
12.30 o'clock. All the old men
and all candidates are to meet at
that hour in the lecture hall of the
Civil Engineering Building, where
Coach Joseph T. England, Capt.
Monroe Firor and Manager Carroll will outline the program of
the year and tell the men of the
traditions to be upheld.
Since Captain Firor is attending the Medical School and cannot
be on hand about Homewood, except at practices, Beverly Smith,
captain of last year's freshman
team and a member of the 'Varsity relay, will assist him in taking charge of the undergraduate
candidates. Guy Leadbetter, a
second-year medical student and
graduate of Bowdoin, will help
the coach again this year by instructing candidates in field work
and will add materially to the
success of the squad by his ability
in the weight events.
A number of former stars of
other universities, who are now in
the Medical School, have been discovered by Firor, and have signified their intention of becoming
members of the squad. Also a
number of sprinters graduated
from Baltimore"prep"schoolsore
working_ out on the cross-country
course with last year's men.
The course is in better shape
than it has been for years, and is
marked all the way by posts painted white. It is approximately two
miles in length. The management
of the team, however, in order to
make sure of the distance covered,
is arranging to have it surveyed,
and this job may be taken over by
some of the engineering students.
If the plans now under consideration are adopted a number of large
cross country meets will be held
on it.
Coach England is desirous of
a large attendance at the organization meeting, as the schedule
now being arranged will require
a big squad to carry it through.
Since this year offers exceptional
opportunities for freshmen, it is
hoped that they will turn out in
large numbers.
All candidates for the track team
have been excused from drill on
Thursdays by Captain Guild.
They must attend the other drills
and lectures, however.

The Johns Hopkins Reserve Officers' Training Corps is to have a
full calibre rifle range or its equivalent by the spring of 1918. According to Captain Guild, plans
the present time are necessarily uncertain, but unless something unforeseen happens Hopkins
is sure to have at least a low calibre range in which the work of a
full calibre range will be closely
simulated, and which will be of
almost equal value to the student
officers.
It is now ungrtain whether the
Johns HopkinW corps will be, allowed to retain the Krag rifles obtained last year from the War Department. It is the' opinion of
Captain Guild that such an event
4 not unlikely in view of the great
need for rifles at the present time.
Should the rifles have to be turned
in, the use of a full range would
of course be out of the question,
and the lower calibre range would
have to be substituted.
A suitable distinguishing device
for the Johns Hopkins Corps,
probably an adaptation of the
Johns Hopkins seal, is to be worn
on the campaign hats and swagger
sticks are to be carried by the officers as an insignia of rank.
The officers of the corps express
praticular satisfaction with regard to the work of the• recruit
company. The progress has been
such as to warrant the prediction
that the recruit company as a distinct unit will soon be a thing of
the past.
General orders issued last Friday set the program for drills and
outline the conduct of both individuals and battalion for the coming year. On drill days the first
call is to be at 4.05 P. M., the assembly at 4.10 and the recall at 6.
Monday and Thursday are set as
drill days for the entire battalion,
and Tuesday for optional drills
for the companies in rotation.
During inclement weather assembly will take place in the driveway
tunnel of Gilman Hall.
Particular stress 'is laid upon
the necessity of the elimination
of lateness and tardiness in the
companies. Opportunities to make
up drills will be given but the
'be espepenalties this year will
cially heavy, ana every effort will
be made to stamp out the evil.
Captain Guild strongly recommends the wearing of the uniform
at all times by the men.

The membership of the faculty
and students of the engineering
department has been greatly reduced by enlistments in war service.
One fourth of last year's faculty
of the department of civil engineering is now engaged in war
work. Professor Frank L. Weaver, instructor in civil engineering,
is a first lieutenant in the 305th
Engineers, U. S. A., stationed at
Fort Lee, Va.
Of a class of twelve juniors in
civil engineering last year, five
have returned as seniors; the remaining seven are in the army.
An addition of about three hundred volumes has been made during the summer to the library of
the civil engineering department.
In the department of electrical
engineering, Dr. J. B. Whitehead
and Dr. William B. Kouwenhoven
have been engaged in Government
service during the summer. Dr.
Whitehead is now devoting all and
Dr. Kouwenhoven part of his time
to scientific research work for the
Government. Dr. Kouwenhoven
and Mr. M. W. Pullen, instructor
in eletcrical engineering, have
charge of Dr. Whitehead's day
classes.
The night courses in electrical
engineering are in charge of Mr.
F. W. Lieberknecht and J. B. Arthur, instructor in electrical engineering in the U. S. Naval
Academy.
Henry S. Baker, Elbridge G.
Hall and Louis McComas Young,
former students, have commissions
in the army.
There are seven in the senior
class in electrical engineering
this year, as compared with nine
last year. Twenty-five juniors
have returned in this course.
In the department of mechanical
engineering, Mr. Julian C. Smallwood, instructor in mechanical
engineering, has charge of the day
and night classes in machine design this year.
Prof. Carl C. Thomas, professor
of mechanical engineering,who has
been appointed head of the Maritime Navigation Schools of the
U. S. Shipping Board, has charge
of the day and night courses in
navigation and maritime,engineering. He will be assisted by Instructor William J. Dand in the
day courses and by Prof. J. G.
Russell and Howard Lyons, both
of the faculty of the U. S. Naval
Academy, in the night courses in
marine engineering. Mr. W. M.

The first organization meeting
of the Johns Hopkins Musical
Clubs, held on Tuesday, October
9, was well attended. Manager
Kellum gave a brief outline of the
work to be done during the coming year.
It was announced that the work
of the clubs during the past has
gained them a number of excellent
bookings for this season, and that
the financial outlook is good. Assurances were given of the return
of Mr. Spieker as director.
Glee and Musical Club practice
will be held on Wednesday and
Monday nights, respectively.

$250 IS UNDERGRADUATE GOAL
Dr. Raney, Hopkins Librarian, Calls on
Students to Contribute at Once
and Show Reasons for
Appeal.

At a mass-meeting a week ago
Wednesday, Dr. M. Llewellyn Raney, librarian of the Johns Hopkins University, made an appeal
for student contribution to the
Library Fund for Soldiers and
Sailors, and a clock was set up
over the postoffice window to show
the amounts subscribed. The hand
has stuck at $73.50. The following is a further appeal from Dr.
Raney, who is in charge of the
raising of the fund at Hopkins:
The optimist may often find it
difficult to get a toe-hold in present day events, but it is well worth
a tenacious remembrance that
books for soldiers and sailors have
place in the measures adopted by
the War and Navy Departments
in this conflict. A military measure, not one philanthropic. Germany saw this first, and when her
troops took the field a traveling
library accompanied each army
corps. In her endless rehearsals
for"Der Tag"she had discovered in
books .a piece of stage business
necessary for getting the play over
the footlights. England awoke to
it, as to much else, when the call
for books came from the men themselves in training, on the firing
line, in the hospital—a call overwhelming all existing agencies for
supply. Four organizations born
in succession have failed to meet
the demand, though one of them
has sent 9,000,000 books and periodicals, and the four of them today
despatch 100,000 a week.
•
Our Secretary of War, a Hopkins man, is a political idealist,
but when, under his auspices, a
call for $1,000,000 for books goes
to America, it is the call of a practical militarist. In books soldiers,
no matter what their previous habits as to reading have been, have
found the anodyne necessary for
forgetting the unnatural present,
preserving the balance necessary
to effective military service, and
the means of keeping somewhat
in contact with the life civilian
that is to follow.
This is the first, the last and the
only call that the Government has
issued to educational institutions
as such. The response in Baltimore of such institutions has been
splenaid. The public school children have massed up their pennies
to a height of over $1,670. From
Goucher will come $750 from
Johns Hopkins to date over $1,650 has come, but the readers of
THE NEWS-LETTER have not yet
given their amount. The undergraduate body has to date contributed $73.50. It should not be
satisfied with a red cent less than
$250. Wake up boys! Come
across!

Corn stalks standing in the
shock and dried-up plants are the
remaining evidence of the success
of what was dubbed last spring
"The Faculty Farm:" It is said
that the gardens planted last
May north of the Johns Hopkins
Club grew green and promising
and parts even bore fruit. Much
of the produce, however, suffered
because of the ravages of ravenous
grasshoppers and the unexpected
sprouting of weeds. Many of
those, however, who industriously
cared for their gardens enjoyed
the produce of their labors at the
dinner table.
All those students who last year
harbored doubts that such an enterprise could attain the point of
fruition would have received a severe shock if they visited the vegetable gardens early this summer.
They will find out that a Greek
professor knows just as much
about beans as about the Iliad,
and that the chemistry man has
achieved a distinct success with
beets and onions.
One of the largest harvests was
the corn crop. A gentleman farmer of the faculty, when interviewed, claimed that his particular garden had on it more ears of
corn per square foot than any
other farm in the State. As he is
a professor of mathematics he is
willing to furnish statistics to
prove his contentions.
Many of the other gardens had
remarkable rows of corn, but their
beans ran a close second. The lima
bean crop was unusually large;
and this delicacy must have been
very popular, for on close observation of the plants it is seen that
hardly a bean has been overlooked
and allowed to remain unplucked.
Many headless stalks of cabbage
may be observed. However, the
disappearance of the heads remain
a mystery, since, as one would-be
farmer remarked,"sauerkraut was
'verboten' by the declaration of
war."
Now the gardens, once such a
scene of industrious hoeing and
planting, stand neglected, awaiting recultivation next spring;
but it has been reported by a
visionary student that the ghost
of the scarecrow is still keeping
watch over his domain.

"Join the Battalion."
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

Sir—Even in this time of national stress some of us seem to be
unmindful of the tremendous responsibilities which rest upon us.
Our sense of duty should become
the greater when considered that
we are members of an institution
which is foremost in the ranks to
offer all that it has to its country.
The professors of our faculty have
proven themselves invaluable to
the Government. What have we,
as undergraduates of Hopkins, to
offer our country when it calls us?
Above all other things we want to
be able to give an acute mind and
a sound body.
Probably there has been no better opportunity in the history of
the University to show at once
loyalty to our Alma Mater and patriotism to our country than that
afforded by the Reserve Officers'
Training Corps. I appeal especially to the upper classmen who
are looking lightly upon military
training. The degree of seriousnegs with which the question
Should be considered cannot be
over-estimated. That you are
benefiting yourself by joining the
corps is trivial; that you are aiding your country in earnestness
of spirit is the all-important feature. Join the battalion—it is a
Government institution. Where
are the "loyal sons of Hopkins?"
Let's have some real, old-time Hopkins spirit! A little pep!

freshmen—look on the regulations
as no more than a mild form of
hazing to make new students uncomfortable. This childish idea,
of course, has no place in the real
purpose of putting these restrictions upon the behavior of freshmen. The actual motive behind it
all, as I see it, is making the
new men loyal, • working, living
parts of the one great organism—
the Johns Hopkins University.
First of all, the first-year student
must be made to realize that when
he.enters the University he is being made heir to all that has been
left by those who have gone before—to its splendid enducational
advantages, to its glorious traditions, to its opportunities for selfbetterment. He must be impressed
by the earnestness, the dignity of
the institution; he must feel the
significance of linking his name
with that of a university whose
reputation for the zealous pursuit
of learning is little less than
world-wide. He should thrill with
the sense of loyalty to that institution; with a feeling of deep obligation that cannot be repaid; with
a consciousness of the duty to uphold its good name at any cost.
And at the same time, he sould be
aware of his individual littleness
in the great complexity of the University; he should realize his extreme relative unimportance. After all, the secret of it all is in humility—not in humiliation. And if
the first-year men will regard them
in this light, the freshman regulations will go far in accomplishing
their aim.

CONSTITUTION BEING DRAWN UP
Hopkins Advisory Council for Interscholastic Athletic League Making
Fall Plans—Opinions of School
Athletic Associations Solicited.

The Hopkins Advisory Council
for the Interscholastic Athletic
League of the Preparatory Schools
of Baltimore, which was founded
last spring by Mr. Theodore Kistler, instructor of gymnastics at
the University, will hold its first
meeting of the year at an early
date. Plans for the coming year
are being formulated by Monroe
Firor, secretary of the Council,
and it is probable that the immediate work of the Hopkins men will
be to supervise interscholastic
basket-ball.
A committee, on which Firor
and President Wolfe, of the Athletic Association are serving, is
now engaged in drawing up a constitution. The athletic associations of the city "prep" schools
have been asked to send in their
opinion as to what the character
and limitations of the league
should be and express the immediate desires of their schools in regard to interscholastic athletics.
These statements are to be influential in determining the scope of
the constitution.
The Council, which is composed
of former members of Baltimore
preparatory schools, has as its
purpose the stimulation and supervision of sports among "prep"
schools. Last spring it offered a
trophy to the champion baseball
team of the city, but made no
award because of a dispute which
arose as to which institution was
the rightful winner. During this
year, however if its plans become
effective, the'
Council will play a
large part in furthering friendly
athletic relations among the city
schools.

July 6. I am very much pleased

has already begun. The other day

we welcome you Americans so

Both .teams scored touchdowns

Hopkins came right back. Purcell ran back the kick-off 20 yards.
Jones fought his way for 20 more.
Jones made all but first down on
the next play and Purcell took it
over. Jones, Carey and Purcell
made three more first downs, the
ball was on Gettysburg's 19-yard
line, but the Blue and Gold team
closed up the holes on the next
two plays. Then Carey threw a
pass heading right between the
goal posts. Just as a Gettysburg
man, in the very shadow of the
goal posts, thought he had the
ball, it glanced his shoulder and
bounced away, only to fall in the
wide-stretched arms of Alec Wolfe,
who was behind the goal line and
apparently wide-awake to just
such an opportunity. Schmidt
tried hard to win the game with

The third period opened with
both teams fighting desperately.
The Hopkins battle-cry, "Speed
the plow," resounded down the
field as Hopkins took the ball in
mid-field. On the second play,
Jones got away from 30 yards.
Jones and Purcell, alternately
carrying the ball, made a first
down and then another. Again
Hopkins had the ball on Gettysburg's 20-yard line; three line
plunges failed to gain anything
and Schmidt dropped back for a
drop-kick, which went wide only
by a few inches. Hopkins had the
ball during most of the remaining
three minutes of the game.

The first official figures for student enrollment at the University
this year have been given out by
the registrar's office. In view of
the numerous enlistments during
last spring and summer, these figures will be of special interest to
the members of the upper classes
who are anxious to know just
where they stand.
There are 47 men enrolled in
the Senior Class; this number inincludes the engineering men who
entered with the present Junior
Class and who are completing the
course in three years. The Senior
Class has also been augmented by
a number of men who entered
college this year or last year
with credit from outside colleges.
The Senior Class, therefore,'will
be much larger than was generally
expected. On the other hand, the
Junior Class numbers only 60,
which is much below the general
estimate of its class officers. One
hundred and thirty men, out of
the 157 who finished their first
year, returned as members of the
Sophomore Class. The Freshman
Class has 161 members enrolled—
approximately the same number
of men who entered the University
last year. There are four students
following special courses at the
University. This makes a total of
404 undergraduates for the new
academic year.
